Lesson 2: The Aotearoa Wars

Re-framing the "Land Wars" as a conflict over sovereignty, analyzing the sophisticated strategies of MÄori leaders.

Lesson Objectives

  • Students will be able to explain the primary causes of the Aotearoa Wars from a MÄori perspective.
  • Students will identify key MÄori leaders and their diverse strategies of resistance.
  • Students will analyze the technological and tactical innovations developed by MÄori during the wars.
  • Students will compare and contrast different perspectives on the same historical events.

Core Resources & Handouts

This lesson explores the Aotearoa Wars through the lens of MÄori leadership, strategy, and innovation.

1. Leadership Profiles: Aotearoa Wars

Introduces students to the diverse strategies and philosophies of key MÄori resistance leaders like Te Kooti, Te Whiti, and TÄ«tokowaru.

2. MÄori Military Innovation Study

An analysis of MÄori military technology and tactics, focusing on the revolutionary design of the gunfighter pÄ and guerrilla warfare.

3. Fortification Engineering: PÄ Design

A technical deep-dive into the engineering principles of the gunfighter pÄ, comparing it to European fortifications of the era.

4. Colonial vs. MÄori Perspective Comparison

A primary source analysis activity where students compare different accounts of the same event to identify bias and propaganda.

5. Wars Strategy Analysis

A high-level comparison of conventional and guerrilla warfare strategies, and the cultural and environmental factors that influenced them.

Suggested Lesson Flow

  1. Introduction: Begin with the "Leadership Profiles" to introduce the key figures and their motivations.
  2. Technical Analysis: Use the "Military Innovation" and "Fortification Engineering" handouts to explore the 'how' of MÄori resistance.
  3. Perspective Taking: The "Perspective Comparison" handout is a powerful mid-lesson activity for developing critical thinking.
  4. Synthesis & Strategy: Use the "Wars Strategy Analysis" to bring all the concepts together and facilitate a high-level discussion.
